results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 29]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is about a trip around North Queensland to locations such as Townsville and National Parks. Wallace films the wonderful brolga water birds of the title but also captures the dramatic Wallaman Falls in Girringun Park, which is Australia’s highest permanent single drop waterfall, and the Little Crystal Creek Bridge on Mount Spec Rd in Paluma Range National Park. The bridge and Mt Spec Road are of particular interest as both are listed heritage sites on the Queensland Heritage Register and were constructed during the Great Depression in the 1930s using mostly unskilled labour and with the application of ‘Unemployment Relief Scheme’ funds. Mt Spec Road remains substantially intact throughout the 18km of its length and demonstrates an extensive and now uncommon use of concrete arch culverts, dry stone walling and stone-paved gutters. Also, the very picturesque bridge is the only identified concrete arch bridge dressed with stone remaining in service in Queensland.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Where Brolgas Dance’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:00:27:00 the ‘Air Cloud’ tour boat moored at a pier
00:00:32:00 looking out from the pier over a lake or river followed by boats sitting on sand and mud when the tide is out and remains of old jettys
00:01:03:00 views of boats moored at jettys and piers
00:02:09:00 sunflowers in the foreground of mountains
00:02:27:00 the ‘Burdekin Bridge’ rail and car bridge in Queensland
00:03:38:00 sugar cane, wetlands and lily pads and roaming cattle
00:04:13:00 a large spider web in the wetlands complete with black spider in the middle
00:04:30:00 driving through Townsville in Queensland, and past the ‘T&G Building’
00:06:13:00 views of brolgas standing in grass and flying overhead
00:07:52:00 signs for ‘Mt Spec National Park’ and ‘Little Crystal Creek’
00:07:59:00 views of the Little Crystal Creek Bridge and the creek itself with its lovely rocky banks
00:08:24:00 a roadside picnic and exploring under the bridge
00:08:54:00 sign for ‘McClelland Bridge’ followed by scenic views of mountains and waterways
00:10:06:00 driving through the rainforest
00:10:48:00 views of the dramatic Wallaman Falls
00:11:01:00 sign for the Falls with facts and information for campers
00:11:34:00 sightseers at a lookout
00:12:03:00 a small modest road bridge
00:12:16:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: Think twice
results.creator_credit: James Levy, Keith Gow, Norma Disher and Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia. Film Unit.
results.brief_description:
This 1958 film demonstrates the hazards associated with the boilermaking trade. It outlines the dangers of heat, infrared and ultraviolet rays and fumes, which are encountered with oxyacetylene and electric arc welding. It shows how accidents happen with each of these dangers and the types of injury suffered, including burns, eye injury and blindness, and serious illness caused by inhalation of fumes. It also shows how accidental explosions can occur when using welding equipment, and the importance of safe practices when welding, particularly in confined spaces.

The film emphasises the protective gear and equipment recommended at the time that should be used in order to avoid these hazards. It also shows teenage apprentices, some very young, being trained in safety practices. The film takes place at Cockatoo Docks and Engineering Company, a shipbuilding company that operated on Cockatoo Island, Sydney, between 1933 and 1992.

Produced by the Waterside Workers’ Federation of Australia Film Unit and presented by the Boilermakers’ Society of Australia and Protector Safety Products Pty. Ltd. Sydney, Australia.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be incorrectly dressed
results.creator_credit: Stan Murdoch, Ron Collins, Reg Perier and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1962 film demonstrates the need for various types of protective clothing and equipment when working with abrasives, welding, lead and chemicals. Accompanied by an instructional narration, the film shows footage of workers in various industries, and the need for protective glasses, face shields, respirators, gloves, footwear and clothing.

Produced by the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be a fall guy
results.creator_credit: Stan Murdoch, Ron Collins, Reg Perier and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1962 instructional film demonstrates safety regulations on building sites in Sydney, New South Wales. Narrated by a didactic voiceover, the film dramatises the do’s and dont’s of construction sites, including good housekeeping, adequate lighting, head protection, guard rails, proper scaffolding and safety lines. It emphasises the risks of carelessness and overconfidence of builders working without proper safety equipment.

In order to demonstrate this, the film restages several accidents, including a man falling down an open lift shaft after the guard rail was removed by a fellow builder. The film also includes footage of riggers climbing steel frames on multi-story buildings without safety harnesses, in what would have been standard practice in this era.

Produced by the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: [The Tatler social newsreel]
results.brief_description: This film was one of the many documentaries shot in Victoria by Efftee Studios in the early 30s. In this newsreel compiled and narrated by Peter Newmarch of “The Truth” newspaper and shot by Bert Nicholas, several Melbourne socialites are featured at various functions: a social party in South Yarra, the first official meeting of the Centenary Dog Club at the Melbourne Showground and Ron Cameron’s Riding School. NOTE: No titles included.

results.title: Factory to farm
results.brief_description: Shows the various stages in the manufacture of farm implements and machinery and their use on Australian wheat farms during the 1920s. An important film on Australian history, both from farming and the “Sunshine Harvester Factory” points of view. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Footscray 1911
results.brief_description: Scenes of Footscray around 1911. Shows street scenes, transport, recreation and clothing. Recognizable scenes include Nicholson Street and Forges Store. Footscray Railway Station and Federal Hall.

results.title: Glimpses of Australia. [No. 02?]
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items include: 1. A lesson in geography - shows the size of Australia in relation to Scandinavia and Europe. 2. Warburton District - located on the Great Dividing Range, Victoria, shows scenery and inhabitants. 3. The Princes Highway - from Lakes Entrance to Narooma inlet. Shows Lakes Entrance locals and holiday-makers; an Australian First Nations person fishing with a spear; Narooma’s beautiful inlet; oyster fishing and eating. 4. Animal bandits - animals dance to the sound of birds; they form a band but their tunes are unbearable until they attend Professor Heron’s school of music.

results.title: [Kodak Cinegraph compilation. No. 05]
results.brief_description: A compilation of silent newsreels including: 1. Coronation of (probably) King George V. 2. The tribute of the forest - The ‘Hoop Pine’ of Queensland used for making matches and butter boxes. An example of the “winch and steel cable” method (?) - logging in Queensland. Bullock teams also shown hauling logs. 3. Burton Holmes’ Film Reels of Travel - alpine vistas. 4. Alfred Weiss presents ‘Another kick coming’. 5. Sheep dipping and general farm scenes. 6. Granite Quarry in action. 7. Steel production.

results.title: Victoria's welcome to press delegates
results.brief_description: Viscount Burnham is welcomed by S.S. Argyle, M.L.A. Chief Secretary of Victoria. Items of interest are pointed out, indicating Victoria’s development as a state including footage of Sir John Monash, development of the Hume Weir, Yallourn Open Cut mine, the Dandenong Ranges/Ferntree Gully, Yarra Glen, Camperdown, Rochester, the “Better Farming Train”, Bendigo, Geelong and Geelong Grammar, and Ballarat. Source: National Film and Sound Archive.
